page.title: 06Chickney, birds & animals
page.content: Many birds were seen or known to the inhabitants of the area. Swans and other water owl are being encouraged by the restoration of a lake, believed to be 1000 years old at the Rookery, east of Horham Hall. The keen eyed observer can see kingfisher, moorhen, doves, fly catchers, willow warblers, magpies, owls, pheasant, partridge and kestral; with the more common birds like sparrow, starling blackbirds, thrushes, finches, tits, robins, crows, rooks and wood pigeon. The animal life is of course, more elusive, but there was much evidence of rabbits and bares. Grey squirrels live in the woods and hunting no longer takes place in the area, foxes are increasing in numbers. Other mammals include shrews, field mice, brown rats, weasels and moles. Several bats have been observed by the church.
